statement.tex: %text An open box with a square base is to be made out of a given quantity of cardboard of area $c^2$ square units. Show that the maximum volume of the box is $\dfrac{c^3}{6\sqrt{3}}$ cubic units. %

step.context: %text Given a box with a square base (see figure), are the following assertions also true? (see equations below the figure) %
step.reason:
%text It is a box with a \underline\text{square base}. But no one ever said that it is a square box.
Hence, it is \underline\text{not necessary} that $x=y$.
Moreover, it is an \underline\text{open} box. Which means that it has no top. Hence, if we have $c^2$ square units of cardboard, then
% \begin{align} c^2 &= \underbrace{4xy}_{\text{4 faces}} + \underbrace{x^2}_\text{base} \end{align}

step.context: \textbf{Volume of the box}\\ %text If $V$ be the volume of the box, then given the results of Step 1, would the following be true? %
%text Given that $V = \dfrac{c^2x-x^3}{4}$, are the following assertions correct? %
step.reason: %text At a maxima, $\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x)=0$ and $\dfrac{d^2 f(x)}{dx^2}\lt 0$. Therefore, % \begin{align} V = \frac{c^2x - x^3}{4}&\implies\frac{dV}{dx} = \frac{1}{4}\cdot (c^2 - 3x^2)\\ \therefore \frac{dV}{dx}= 0 &\implies c^2 - 3x^2 = 0\text{ or }x = \frac{c}{\sqrt{3}}\\ \text{Also, }\frac{d^2V}{dx^2} &= \underbrace{\frac{1}{4}\cdot (0-6x)\lt 0}_{\text{Because }x\gt 0}\\ &\implies\text{ maxima} \\ \therefore V_\text{maximum} &= \frac{x}{4}\cdot (c^2 - x^2) \\ &=\underbrace{\frac{\frac{c}{\sqrt{3}}}{4}\cdot\left(c^2-\frac{c^2}{3}\right)}_{x=\frac{c}{\sqrt{3}}}\\ &= \frac{c}{4\sqrt{3}}\cdot\frac{2c^2}{3} = \frac{c^3}{6\sqrt{3}} \end{align}
